An Indian war dance is an important inci-
dent in the passing events of village. lhe
whole population is assembled and feast
provided for all. The warriors are painted
and prepared as for battle. A post is firm-
ly planted in the ground, and the singers, the
drummers, and other instrumental musi-
clans, are seated within the circle formed by
dancers and the spectators The music and
dance begin. The warriors exert them
selves with great energy. Every muscle is
in action, and there is the most perfect CON
cord between the music and their move
ments. They branlish their weapons with
such apparcnt fury. that fatal accidents seem
unavoidable. Presently q warrior leaves
the circle, and with his tomahawk or cassettc,
strikes the post. The music and dancing
cease, and profound silence ensues. lie then
recounts with loud voice, his military a.
chievcments He describes the battles ne
has fought, the prisoners he has captured,
the scalps he has taken. lie points 20 MS
wounds and produces his trophies. lie ac'
companies his narrative with the actual rep
resentation of his exploits, and the mimic
engagement, the advance and the retreat, are
exhibited to his nation as they really occur
red. There is no exaggeration, and no mis-
representation. 1t would be Infamous for
a warrior to boast of deeds he never per-
formed. II the attempt were made, some
one would approach and throw dirt IN his
face. saving, i do this to cover your shame.
for the first time you see an enemy you Will
tremble.' But such an indignity Is rarely
necessary, and as the war parties generally
contain many individuals, the character and
conduct of every warrior are well KNOWN
Shouts Of applause accompany the narration.
propo,tioned in duration and intensity to the
interest it excites. His station IN the circle
IS then resumed by the actor, and the dance
proceeds till it is interrupted in similar
nannet

II The New. York Commercial Adver-
tiSer, says that on Sunday morning last,
three young men took small boat from the
sloop Patriot, at Spring street wharf, with
the intention of proceeding on sailing ex-
cursion, but when they had reached about
midway of the river. sudden flaw capsiz-
ed the boat, and Alexander Mackay, aged
about 10 years, was drowned; the two others
were enabled to reach the shore. Mackay
has Lett widowed mother, who is inconso-
liable at the loss of her only SOMA son, too,
who had been tcnderly brought up, and
who yesterday was urged, by all the tender
ties OF an aiectionate mother, to desist from
his boat excursions OH the Sabbath. We un-
derstand the last words of the mother to him
we're" alexander, if you SO this day,
shall never see you again"





Extract of letter from respectable res
ident in the Cherokee naton-"In this quar-
ter very little news offers, except what the
public papers furnish you, in regard to the
Georgia clamor respecting Indian lands, &c.
Ihcindians are progressing and pursuing the
arts of civilization, regardless of the passing
events around them, having full confidence
in the General Government affordng the
RI finn fl,t than Ia, trpaties The her
okees have it in view to establish a press for
the purpose of circulating general intelli-
genee among their people. 1t may propa-
bly, BE- new to you to hear that real Chero-
kee has invented an alphabet containing sc
characters, containing all the sounds in their
tongue: each character represents syila-
BILE, and 50 easily acquired by the Indians,
that they correspond with each other with
as much facility as the whites do"


Recently in one ofthe Philadelphia courts, an
action for a breach of promise of marriage waa
brought against female. 1t appeared in evil
dcnce that the supposed promise was made III
Jest; a conclusion which WAS so much coroborat
cd by the disparity of the parties concerned, that
the jury gave 4 verdict for the defendant.


Fires IN Cantop.--By the ship Nautilus, at
Boston, we learn that there have been two fires
in Canton. The first took piece in October and
DESTROYED from four to five hundred houses At
the French Folly. The second was in Novem-
her, in about the same place where there was
fire some years since, ard consumed 700 houses.
No American or English property was destoycd.


The motion to discharge Isaac B. Desha.
on the ground Of the unconstitutionahty OF
the venue law, has been overruled by the
Court, and the prisoner permitted to enter
into new recognizance for his appearance
at the June term. The trial was continued
on the motion of the attorney for the COM
onwealth--several of the most important
witnesses being absent from the State.

It is stated that the Yearly Meeting of Friends,
late in Session in Philadelphia, have appropriate
cd Three Thousand Dollars, towards defraying
the expenses of certain Free People Of Color,
from the State of North Carolina, {whcre their
laws will not permit them to remain,) to Liberia,
Hayti, and the Free States as they may prefer,


The brig Caledonia, Captain Robinson,
at the port of Baltimore, on Saturday, sailed
from Rio Grande on TIE second Of March.
We learn, says the American, that reports
had reached that town, Of the occurrence
of a severe battle between the Brazilian and
Buenos Ayrean armies. No positive intelh-
gence Of the result had been permitted to
transpirc, although il vas believed the au-
theritics had received the particulars. The
reports in circulation, and they were gene
rally credited. were, that the Brazilians had
met with an absolute defeat, and were only
preserved from teal destruction, by the
presence Of the Austrian soliitrs, ii body OF
which the Emperor has ia his service
This runour Of the defeat of the Brazilian
Army, our readers may recollect, cores
ponds with the report which has already
reached us from Rio dc Janeiro. The scene
of action was about $50 mics from RID
Grande.


"Shc has flushed her education" said my
friend. Finished her education said Just
as though young lady's education was a
stocking or rather a bonnet, and now it was
tn be placed in the band box, 10 be displayed
10 visitors, and worn only on set occasions.---
Mr.. Editor, protest the doing up and fin
lshing off young lady's education wish her
tcens-ust at that time when she begins, II
she ever does begin, to THiNE. young
mau has Just acquired at one-and-twenty,
the clements Of education, ard is prepared
to study advantageouSly according to his
own discretion; but young lady has done
fnished-thc circle OF her science is com
plcte; and she is ready Tor any station in
life, that may be thrown in her way.--Now,
WHY, in the name OF common sense, may not
a woman THINK and if she may think. why
NAV she not study; and acquire profitable
food for thought!


There is lady, o! whom I have some
knowledge, that FINISHED her education, .
bv leaving peculiarly good advantages at an
early age. She is now wife and mother Of
six children. She plays well upon the piano
sings sweetly-dances elegantly--is very
polite, Stc.--but her husband must, and ac-
tually does, put all the children to bed, and
takes care of them through the night; and as
to her tablc--the bread is eXecrabc, to one
who has visited his grand mothers pantry
and her cofTce-O her coffee it would cost
her head, if the very scent of it reached the
Grand Turks palace--and yet the lady has
finished education"

RAND .Tust,ce.-Among facts undeniable,
NAV be classed' the celerity will, which
criminal affairs are despatched in Turkey
The citation, the defence, the receivai OF teS-
timony and argument, the sentence and the
application of punishment pass in fright
fully laconc manner. IN the recent distur-
Dances at Constantinoplc, three Janssary
leaders were arrested and carried before the
Grand Vizier who thus questioned them
"Have YOU any complaint to make against
your SOVEREIGN, Are YOU not paid, ted, and
clothetl?'' ayes. our Sovereign has paid us.
fed us. clothed u.s." "What has urged you
then to revolt" IT. is hrs wishing to break
the Janssaries." 81 sentence YOU to be
strangled." They were strangled.


Claiborne, (Alab.( March 23.


A Precious .7nimal-A few days ago a re-
markahle circumstance took place in this coun-
w. As three women belonging TO Mr.. J. +.
Lovett, were ascending the hill on the south side
Of Rig Greek, one with child about months
old in her arms they attacked by a large
he wildcat t--the animal made at the woman with
the child, canght the child bv the leg and Bit it,
tore the woman badly with his claws, and threw
her down; the child having handkerchief on its
head the animal in second attempt at the
child, tore the handkerchief in pieces that was
on It's head.--Thc mother of the child who was
present, saw its danger, and made violent ef-
fort to save it. and in the struggle seized the cat
BY the neck fen on it, and held fast her grip m
I'll the other two women despatched him with
rocks. The mother ofthe child was very much
injured by the animal, and the child was nearly
killed Apprchensions are entertained that the
atmrst have labored under the influence of hy-
drophobia informant adds, that the cat
was extraordinary large.

An Indian war dance is an important inci-

whole population is assembled and feast
provided for all. The warriors are painted
and prepared as for battle. A post is firm-

cord between the music and their move

such apparcnt fury. that fatal accidents seem

strikes the post. The music and dancing
cease, and profound silence ensues. lie then

chievcments He describes the battles ne
has fought, the prisoners he has captured,

wounds and produces his trophies. lie ac'
companies his narrative with the actual rep
resentation of his exploits, and the mimic
engagement, the advance and the retreat, are

red. There is no exaggeration, and no mis-
representation. 1t would be Infamous for
a warrior to boast of deeds he never per-
formed. II the attempt were made, some
one would approach and throw dirt IN his
face. saving, i do this to cover your shame.
for the first time you see an enemy you Will

No American or English property was destoycd.


The motion to discharge Isaac B. Desha.
on the ground Of the unconstitutionahty OF
the venue law, has been overruled by the
Court, and the prisoner permitted to enter
into new recognizance for his appearance
at the June term. The trial was continued
on the motion of the attorney for the COM
onwealth--several of the most important
witnesses being absent from the State.

It is stated that the Yearly Meeting of Friends,
late in Session in Philadelphia, have appropriate
cd Three Thousand Dollars, towards defraying
the expenses of certain Free People Of Color,
from the State of North Carolina, {whcre their
laws will not permit them to remain,) to Liberia,
Hayti, and the Free States as they may prefer,


The brig Caledonia, Captain Robinson,
at the port of Baltimore, on Saturday, sailed
from Rio Grande on TIE second Of March.
We learn, says the American, that reports
had reached that town, Of the occurrence
of a severe battle between the Brazilian and
Buenos Ayrean armies. No positive intelh-
gence Of the result had been permitted to
transpirc, although il vas believed the au-
theritics had received the particulars. The
reports in circulation, and they were gene
rally credited. were, that the Brazilians had
met with an absolute defeat, and were only
preserved from teal destruction, by the
presence Of the Austrian soliitrs, ii body OF
which the Emperor has ia his service
This runour Of the defeat of the Brazilian
Army, our readers may recollect, cores
ponds with the report which has already
reached us from Rio dc Janeiro. The scene
of action was about $50 mics from RID
Grande.


"Shc has flushed her education" said my
friend. Finished her education said Just
as though young lady's education was a
stocking or rather a bonnet, and now it was
tn be placed in the band box, 10 be displayed
10 visitors, and worn only on set occasions.---
Mr.. Editor, protest the doing up and fin
lshing off young lady's education wish her
tcens-ust at that time when she begins, II
she ever does begin, to THiNE. young
mau has Just acquired at one-and-twenty,
the clements Of education, ard is prepared
to study advantageouSly according to his
own discretion; but young lady has done
fnished-thc circle OF her science is com
plcte; and she is ready Tor any station in
life, that may be thrown in her way.--Now,
WHY, in the name OF common sense, may not
a woman THINK and if she may think. why
NAV she not study; and acquire profitable
food for thought!


There is lady, o! whom I have some
knowledge, that FINISHED her education, .
bv leaving peculiarly good advantages at an
early age. She is now wife and mother Of
six children. She plays well upon the piano
sings sweetly-dances elegantly--is very
polite, Stc.--but her husband must, and ac-
tually does, put all the children to bed, and
takes care of them through the night; and as
to her tablc--the bread is eXecrabc, to one
who has visited his grand mothers pantry
and her cofTce-O her coffee it would cost
her head, if the very scent of it reached the
Grand Turks palace--and yet the lady has
finished education"

full articles.headline: THE HAPPY PAIR.
full articles.article:
Says Dick to Jack, "Your neighbors say
You wrangle with your wife each day."
"Poo, poo," says Jack, "they only Joke,
IT'S now a fortnight since We spoke"

Perhaps among all the astonishing pro
auctions of the vegetable kingdom, there is
"ot one more remarkable than rose recent
" introduced into Europe aad this country
ron China. and thus described in London's
SSafdener's Magazine, published at London.
nT, Mpsa Grevilii, or Greville's China rose:---


ne shoot Of this rose grew eighteen feet
y I rev weeks. and is the most singular of
Me rose tribe that ever came under my OBJ
sssIvation. 1t now covers above one hundred
,- ,se' square, with more than hundred
stusSes OF flowers-some of these have more
M,m %sh nifty buds in cluster, and the whole
,a %a' average about thirty in truss, so that
,h ,as amount of flower buds is little less than
.m ,".ee thousand. But the most astonishing
u''oslty AN is the variety of colours produced
Sn.se .ne buds at first opening-white, light


'4So' deeper blush, light red, darker red,

while engaged in fishing in the Delaware near
the CITY of Trenton, on the 18th INST tell from
the rock whereon he was sitting INTO the water
and was drowned. lis body was soon after re-
covered.

RAND .Tust,ce.-Among facts undeniable,
NAV be classed' the celerity will, which
criminal affairs are despatched in Turkey
The citation, the defence, the receivai OF teS-
timony and argument, the sentence and the
application of punishment pass in fright
fully laconc manner. IN the recent distur-
Dances at Constantinoplc, three Janssary
leaders were arrested and carried before the
Grand Vizier who thus questioned them
"Have YOU any complaint to make against
your SOVEREIGN, Are YOU not paid, ted, and
clothetl?'' ayes. our Sovereign has paid us.
fed us. clothed u.s." "What has urged you
then to revolt" IT. is hrs wishing to break
the Janssaries." 81 sentence YOU to be
strangled." They were strangled.


Claiborne, (Alab.( March 23.


A Precious .7nimal-A few days ago a re-
markahle circumstance took place in this coun-
w. As three women belonging TO Mr.. J. +.
Lovett, were ascending the hill on the south side
Of Rig Greek, one with child about months
old in her arms they attacked by a large
he wildcat t--the animal made at the woman with
the child, canght the child bv the leg and Bit it,
tore the woman badly with his claws, and threw
her down; the child having handkerchief on its
head the animal in second attempt at the
child, tore the handkerchief in pieces that was
on It's head.--Thc mother of the child who was
present, saw its danger, and made violent ef-
fort to save it. and in the struggle seized the cat
BY the neck fen on it, and held fast her grip m
I'll the other two women despatched him with
rocks. The mother ofthe child was very much
injured by the animal, and the child was nearly
killed Apprchensions are entertained that the
atmrst have labored under the influence of hy-
drophobia informant adds, that the cat
was extraordinary large.

d1vs past the atmosphere has been literally fill
ed with them. They appear to be unusually
!irTe, but incapable of fimparting any disagreea-

Fires IN Cantop--By the ship Nautilus, al
Boston, we learn that there have been two fires
in Canton. The first took piece in October and
destroyed from four TO five hundred houses al
the French Folly. The second was in Novem-
her in about the same place where there was
fire some years since, ard consumed 700 houses.
No American OF English property was destoyed.
